messages.title: Bad Bugs
messages.subtitle: Stink Bugs are a pretty serious garden pest.  Fortunately, birds, toads, spiders, praying mantis, and parasitic wasps all love to eat them!

messages.title: Aphids
messages.subtitle: Aphids love to munch on lupine as well as rose bushes and can quickly overtake a plant.   Spraying them with a dish soap/water mix and then hosing off the plant with plain water can help control aphids

messages.title: Squash Bug
messages.subtitle: Squash Bug eggs might be pretty, shiny coppery little orbs, but you don't want to see them on your squash plants.  They will hatch into little gray nymphs and then mature into destructive squash bugs, so destroy any you see.

messages.title: Cucumber Beetles
messages.subtitle: Cucumber Beetles are another menace to your garden. They will munch on pretty much any squash or melons, so my garden is like a buffet for them. This guy had to go, pretty as he may be. Planting marigolds and catnip, as well as mulching the plants, can help deter the cucumber beetle.

messages.title: June Bugs and Japanese Beetles
messages.subtitle: June Bugs and Japanese Beetles are not welcome in the garden either. More treats for our chickens! I always bring a mason jar with me to the garden and scoop any bad bugs I find into it. Then it's off to the chicken coop with the bugs along with any dropped blossoms and overripe or bug-eaten produce I find in the garden.

messages.title: Cabbage Worms
messages.subtitle: Cabbage Worms are another pest you don't want to see. They will chew holes in your kale, cabbage, turnip, radish, broccoli, and cauliflower leaves.  They often hide on the underside of leaves, so sometimes your first sign of an infestation (besides the raggedy holes in the plant leaves) is tiny black spots on the leaves which is their poop.

messages.title: Colorado Potato Beetles
messages.subtitle: Colorado Potato Beetles will happily also eat your tomatoes, peppers, and eggplant, since they are also in the Solanaceae family, along with white potatoes.  The eggs are bright yellow and can be found on the underside of leaves, the larvae have bulbous bodies and blackheads, and the adults have telltale stripes.

messages.title: Grasshoppers
messages.subtitle: Grasshoppers are another garden menace, although they prefer to munch on grass, so I generally leave the grasshoppers I find in the garden.  Fortunately, chickens love to eat crickets and grasshoppers.

speech: Stink Bugs are a pretty serious garden pest.  Fortunately, birds, toads, spiders, praying mantis, and parasitic wasps all love to eat them!

Aphids love to munch on lupine as well as rose bushes and can quickly overtake a plant.   Spraying them with a dish soap/water mix and then hosing off the plant with plain water can help control aphids

Squash Bug eggs might be pretty, shiny coppery little orbs, but you don't want to see them on your squash plants.  They will hatch into little gray nymphs and then mature into destructive squash bugs, so destroy any you see.

Cucumber Beetles are another menace to your garden. They will munch on pretty much any squash or melons, so my garden is like a buffet for them. This guy had to go, pretty as he may be. Planting marigolds and catnip, as well as mulching the plants, can help deter the cucumber beetle.

data.text: Talk to My friend Agrian about Harm bugs
